# Pathway Controlled Vocabulary

**Title:** Pathway Controlled Vocabulary

**Namespace URI:** http://rs.tdwg.org/dwcpw/values/

**Preferred namespace abbreviation:** dwcpw:

**Date version issued:** put ratification date here

**Date created:** put ratification date here

**Part of TDWG Standard:** http://www.tdwg.org/standards/450

**This version:** http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/doc/pw/iso-date-here

**Latest version:** http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/doc/pw/

**Abstract:** The Darwin Core term `pathway` provides information about the process by which an Organism came to be in a given place at a given time. The Pathway Controlled Vocabulary provides terms that should be used as values for `dwc:pathway` and `dwciri:pathway`. 

**Contributors:** Quentin Groom, Peter Desmet, Lien Reyserhove, Tim Adriaens, Damiano Oldoni, Sonia Vanderhoeven, Steven J Baskauf, Arthur Chapman, Melodie McGeoch, Ramona Walls, John Wieczorek, John R.U. Wilson, Paula F Zermoglio, Annie Simpson

**Creator:** TDWG Darwin Core Maintenance Group

**Bibliographic citation:** Darwin Core Maintenance Group. 2020. Pathway Controlled Vocabulary. Biodiversity Information Standards (TDWG). <http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/doc/pw/>


## 1 Introduction

This document includes terms intended to be used as a controlled value for Darwin Core terms with local name `pathway`. For details and rationale, see Groom et al. 2019. Improving Darwin Core for research and management of alien species. <https://doi.org/10.3897/biss.3.38084>

### 1.1 Status of the content of this document

In Section 4, the values of the `Term IRI`, `Definition`, and `Controlled value` are normative. The value of `Usage` (if it exists for a given term) is normative.  The value of `Has broader concept` is normative. The values of `Term Name` are non-normative, although one can expect that the namespace abbreviation prefix is one commonly used for the term namespace.  `Label` and the values of all other properties (such as `Notes`) are non-normative.

### 1.2 RFC 2119 key words
The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in [RFC 2119](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2119).

## 2 Use of Terms

Due to the requirements of [Section 1.4.3 of the Darwin Core RDF Guide](https://dwc.tdwg.org/rdf/#143-use-of-darwin-core-terms-in-rdf-normative), term IRIs MUST be used as values of `dwciri:pathway`. Controlled value strings MUST be used as values of `dwc:pathway`.

Available at: <a href="http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3066.txt">http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3066.txt</a> .\n</td>

Available at: <a href="http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3066.txt">http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3066.txt</a> .\n</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>

		</tr>

			<td>The personal name of the data collection's legal owner. The name given to the person as a personal name (the first or christian name in western cultures, including middle initials). The given name may contain several words. It is applicable only to people (vCard: N-Given + vCard: N-Middle).</td>

			<td>Examples</td>
			<td><ul class="list-group list-group-flush">

  <li class="list-group-item">Ichiro</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Hans-Werner</li>
</ul></td>

		</tr>
	</thead>

		<tr>
			<td>Term IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/DataSet-Owner-InheritedName">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/DataSet-Owner-InheritedName</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Modified</td>
			<td></td>
		</tr>

		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>InheritedName</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>The inherited name of the data collection owner. This may consist of family names, generational names, a clan name, parents or grandparents personal names, etc. The inherited name (this being the lastname in western cultures) may be compound (e.g. 'Fischer von Waldheim', 'da Selva', 'Silvano Morales'). Depending on culture, the inherited name is not necessarily the name of the parents nor common to a married couple. Therefore, 'family name' should be avoided even though used in vCard (vCard: N-Family).</td>
		</tr>

		<tr>

		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>UnitExtension</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>The extension is temporary and serves only to accommodate urgent inter-version additions to the unit-object schema [in the future to the the various schemas/objects used in ABCD]. <br/><br/>For example, if a specific community (e.g. culture collections) discover that there are elements missing in the current version of ABCD (as they did for 1.2), they communicate that to the group responsible for schema development, who will discuss whether these elements are already accommodated in the schema, if they are not and if they can and should be generalized, and where they should end up in the schema. IF the culture collection community needs to move rapidly (e.g. due to project pressures), they can add these elements to the current version as an extension schema under a structure that follows SDD's CustomExtensions element (CustomExtensions-CustomExtension-Any ##other). In future modular versions of ABCD, such a structure should exist in the root of every object/schema.</td>
		</tr>

Available at: <a href="http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3066.txt">http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3066.txt</a> .\n</td>

	</thead>

		<tr>
			<td>Term IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Unit-Owner-InheritedName">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Unit-Owner-InheritedName</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Modified</td>
			<td></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Term version IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Unit-Owner-InheritedName-2024-11-13">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Unit-Owner-InheritedName-2024-11-13</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>InheritedName</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>The inherited name of the owner of the unit record. This may consist of family names, generational names, a clan name, parents or grandparents personal names, etc. The inherited name (this being the lastname in western cultures) may be compound (e.g. 'Fischer von Waldheim', 'da Selva', 'Silvano Morales'). Depending on culture, the inherited name is not necessarily the name of the parents nor common to a married couple. Therefore, 'family name' should be avoided even though used in vCard (vCard: N-Family).</td>
		</tr>

			<td>Label</td>
			<td>InheritedName</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>The inherited name of the administrative contact for the unit record. This may consist of family names, generational names, a clan name, parents or grandparents personal names, etc. The inherited name (this being the lastname in western cultures) may be compound (e.g. 'Fischer von Waldheim', 'da Selva', 'Silvano Morales'). Therefore, 'family name' should be avoided even though used in vCard (vCard: N-Family).</td>

### 4.8 Identification

<table>
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<th colspan="2"><a id="abcd2_Identification"></a>Term Name  abcd2:Identification</th>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>Term IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Identification">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Identification</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Modified</td>
			<td></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Term version IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Identification-2024-11-13">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Identification-2024-11-13</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>Identification</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>Assignation of a scientific or vernacular name or material classification to the unit. In cases where more than one name applies to a single unit, several identifications should be formed and flagged as preferred. Relationships between differently identified sub-units of the unit can be specified by means of the Identification-Role.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Type</td>
			<td>Class</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<table>
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<th colspan="2"><a id="abcd2_Identification-Date"></a>Term Name  abcd2:Identification-Date</th>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>Term IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Identification-Date">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Identification-Date</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Modified</td>
			<td></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Term version IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Identification-Date-2024-11-13">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Identification-Date-2024-11-13</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>Date</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>The date of the unit identification event. Identification dates are commonly incompletely known (e.g. only the year or year and month) or unknown. Sometimes identification dates are inferred from a researcher's visit or the duration of a loan.<br/><br/>The rather complex ABCD {{{DateTime}}} type is used, although many of its elements are not normally needed. As a rule, only the {{{IsoDateTimeBegin}}} element is mapped, which is the one used for searches and which can be used to construct identification histories. Alternatively, the {{{DateText}}} element can also be used, but it provides only for human readability. <br/><br/>However, the elements for exact time and periods may be useful for time series in laboratory reports that can be formulated as a series of identification events, or where the result of the identification may be influenced by the duration of a detection process.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Type</td>
			<td>Class</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<table>
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<th colspan="2"><a id="abcd2_Identification-DateText"></a>Term Name  abcd2:Identification-DateText</th>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>Term IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Identification-DateText">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Identification-DateText</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Modified</td>
			<td></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Term version IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Identification-DateText-2024-11-13">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Identification-DateText-2024-11-13</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>DateText</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>A text version (alphabetic mixed case and integer) of the date at which the unit identification event took place. This element is meant for use when the date is imprecise, ambiguous or not in a form that satisfies the standard structured date format. It can also be used when it is important to record the verbatim representation of the date or when dates to be recorded are not completely legible. For example the day and month may be decipherable but not the year; the use of this field will allow recording of partially interpreted information.<br/><br/>This field can be used to record generalised date ranges and irresolvable ambiguity such as different day/month order conventions (e.g. US/Europe) or to allow for multiple dates and periods.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Examples</td>
			<td><ul class="list-group list-group-flush">
  <li class="list-group-item">25 [?] 1925</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">3/9/45 [ambiguous day month]</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Spring 1912</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Late 1800s</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">End of 19th Century</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Mid 1978</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Easter 1933</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Post WW2</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Before June 25, 2000</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">After June 25, 2000</li>
</ul></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Type</td>
			<td>Property</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

		</tr>

		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>ISODateTimeBegin</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>The exact date (and time) or beginning of a period representing the unit identification event, expressed in a modified ISO/ANSI 8601 standard structured date format.</td>

		<tr>
			<td>Usage</td>
			<td>The date format looks like this: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS with flexible precision.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Notes</td>
			<td>The date format looks like this: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS with flexible precision.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Examples</td>
			<td>2005-04-10T17:34:56\n2005-04-10T17:34\n2005-04-10T17\n2005-04-10\n2005-04\n2005</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Type</td>
			<td>Property</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>

		</tr>

However, use of UND is discouraged by the W3 consortium.\n\nRecommended values are defined by the following reference: H. Alvestrand, ed. RFC 3066: Tags for the Identification of Languages 1995. However, use of UND is discouraged by the W3 consortium.\n\nRecommended values are defined by the following reference: H. Alvestrand, ed. RFC 3066: Tags for the Identification of Languages 1995. Available at: <a href="http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3066.txt">http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3066.txt</a> .\n</td>

</ul></td>

<table>

		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>

			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/TaxonIdentified-HigherTaxon">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/TaxonIdentified-HigherTaxon</a></td>
		</tr>

			<td>Modified</td>
			<td></td>
		</tr>

			<td>Term version IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/TaxonIdentified-HigherTaxon-2024-11-13">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/TaxonIdentified-HigherTaxon-2024-11-13</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>HigherTaxon</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>The scientific name and rank of a taxon with a rank higher than Genus that is used by the data source to classify the taxon name assigned to the unit in the identification event. Although this is not really within the scope of ABCD's data domain, this item is kept for compatibility reasons (Darwin Core) and because for the time being searches are often executed using this item (although classification may vary considerably in source datasets). Eventually, we hope that this function will largely be replaced by taxon and name services defined and provided elsewhere. It is highly recommended to make use of the rank element, because this is a prerequisit for data transformation to Darwin Core.</td>
		</tr>

			<td>Class</td>
		</tr>

		</tr>
		<tr>

			<td>A generic or higher taxon name (monomial) in accordance with rules of nomenclature and associated with the identified taxon. This is not necessarily the result of the identification event, but a classification added to the result of the identification in the source database.</td>

<table>
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<th colspan="2"><a id="abcd2_PreviousUnit-DateText"></a>Term Name  abcd2:PreviousUnit-DateText</th>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>Term IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/PreviousUnit-DateText">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/PreviousUnit-DateText</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Modified</td>
			<td></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Term version IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/PreviousUnit-DateText-2024-11-13">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/PreviousUnit-DateText-2024-11-13</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>DateText</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>A text version (alphabetic mixed case and integer) of the date(s) during which the unit was held by a previous collection. This element is meant for use when the date is imprecise, ambiguous or not in a form that satisfies the standard structured date format. It can also be used when it is important to record the verbatim representation of the date or when dates to be recorded are not completely legible. For example the day and month may be decipherable but not the year; the use of this field will allow recording of partially interpreted information. <br/><br/>This field can be used to record generalised date ranges and irresolvable ambiguity such as different day/month order conventions (e.g. US/Europe) or to allow for multiple dates and periods. <br/><br/>In the rare instances of dates for periods before the year 0000, BC and similar dates can be recorded in this field.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Examples</td>
			<td><ul class="list-group list-group-flush">
  <li class="list-group-item">25 [?] 1925</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">3/9/45 [ambiguous day month]</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Spring 1912</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Late 1800s</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">End of 19th Century</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Mid 1978</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Easter 1933</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Post WW2</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Before June 25, 2000</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">After June 25, 2000</li>
</ul></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Type</td>
			<td>Property</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

			<td>Label</td>

The year is given in ISO-Date-Time-Begin. <br/><br/>The content range is 1-365 for normal years, 366 for leap years. <br/><br/>Maps to Darwin Core 2: Julian Day.</td>

	<thead>

		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>Term IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/PreviousUnit-ISODateTimeBegin">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/PreviousUnit-ISODateTimeBegin</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Modified</td>

		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Term version IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/PreviousUnit-ISODateTimeBegin-2024-11-13">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/PreviousUnit-ISODateTimeBegin-2024-11-13</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>ISODateTimeBegin</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>The exact date (and time) or beginning of a period during which a previous collection held the specimen, expressed in a modified ISO/ANSI 8601 standard structured date format.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Usage</td>
			<td>The date format looks like this: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS with flexible precision.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Notes</td>
			<td>The date format looks like this: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS with flexible precision.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Examples</td>
			<td>2005-04-10T17:34:56\n2005-04-10T17:34\n2005-04-10T17\n2005-04-10\n2005-04\n2005</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Type</td>
			<td>Property</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

			<td>Label</td>

		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>The inherited name of the person acting as or representing the specimen preparation agent. This may consist of family names, generational names, a clan name, parents or grandparents personal names, etc. The inherited name (this being the lastname in western cultures) may be compound (e.g. 'Fischer von Waldheim', 'da Selva', 'Silvano Morales'). Therefore, 'family name' should be avoided even though used in vCard (vCard: N-Family).</td>

			<td>Term IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Gathering-Country">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Gathering-Country</a></td>

		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>Country</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>Details about the gathering country, such as the representation of the country and its name. This is separate from {{{NamedArea}}} for compatibility reasons.<br/><br/>Maps to Darwin Core 2: Country through either {{{ISO2Letter}}} (future) or {{{CountryName}}} (current). Historical country names and water bodies outside the coastal zone can be entered under named area.<br/><br/>{{{CountryNameDerived}}} is provided for a country name that has been derived (e.g.from a system supplied dictionary) by library consultation or other independent research.<br/><br/>At least one of {{{CountryName}}} or {{{ISO2}}} or {{{ISO3}}} should be present but more are allowed. This should be the political country having jurisdiction over the collection site.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Type</td>

<table>
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<th colspan="2"><a id="abcd2_Gathering-Country-ISO3166Code"></a>Term Name  abcd2:Gathering-Country-ISO3166Code</th>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>Term IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Gathering-Country-ISO3166Code">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Gathering-Country-ISO3166Code</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Modified</td>
			<td></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Term version IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Gathering-Country-ISO3166Code-2024-11-13">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Gathering-Country-ISO3166Code-2024-11-13</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>ISO3166Code</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>The 2-,  3-, or 4-letter code for the representation of the name of the gathering country  using the codes assigned by the International Standards Organisation (ISO).<br/><br/>This field should contain a valid entry as defined by the International Standards Organisation (ISO Standard 3166-1), with the following exception: The 'XXX' or 'XX' code should be used when no country of origin information is provided. The 'XXY' or 'XY' code should be used for non-specific collecting localities, e.g. Africa, SouthEast Asia.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Examples</td>
			<td><ul class="list-group list-group-flush">
  <li class="list-group-item">AU</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">ES</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">FR</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">PG</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">US</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">AUS</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">ESP</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">FRA</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">USA</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">DDDE</li>
</ul></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Type</td>
			<td>Property</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<table>
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<th colspan="2"><a id="abcd2_Gathering-Country-Name"></a>Term Name  abcd2:Gathering-Country-Name</th>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>Term IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Gathering-Country-Name">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Gathering-Country-Name</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Modified</td>
			<td></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Term version IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Gathering-Country-Name-2024-11-13">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Gathering-Country-Name-2024-11-13</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>Name</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>The full name of the country or major region where the specimen was collected, or the observation made.<br/><br/>The use of this element is slightly ambiguous in that local practice might require either a verbatim quote from specimen labels, or standardisation by controlled vocabulary or lookup lists.<br/><br/>It is recommended that the spelling of the country be that which is recognised by the International Standards Organisation (ISO).<br/><br/>For cases where country names or boundaries have changed, it is recommended that new country names be enclosed in square brackets, after the old country name. The 2-letter ISO codes in the ISO Code for Country of Origin field assist with updating and cross referencing country names where boundaries change.<br/><br/>Separate fields for state/province and country are needed to adequately handle the situation with international collections.<br/><br/>If the name of the country where the plant was collected is unknown, then this field should contain the value 'UNKNOWN'. In this case, the ISO Code for Country of Origin field must have the entry 'XX' or 'XY'. All remaining 'location group' fields should be left unfilled.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Examples</td>
			<td><ul class="list-group list-group-flush">
  <li class="list-group-item">Australia</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Commonwealth of Australia</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Iceland</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Republic of Iceland</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Samoa</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Independent State of Samoa</li>
</ul></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Type</td>
			<td>Property</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>language</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>The language of the text in the element carrying this attribute, according to RFC 3066.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Usage</td>
			<td>The value UND (undefined) should be used if the language cannot be set for some reason. However, use of UND is discouraged by the W3 consortium.\n\nRecommended values are defined by the following reference: H. Alvestrand, ed. RFC 3066: Tags for the Identification of Languages 1995. Available at: <a href="http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3066.txt">http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3066.txt</a> .\n</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Notes</td>
			<td>The value UND (undefined) should be used if the language cannot be set for some reason. However, use of UND is discouraged by the W3 consortium.\n\nRecommended values are defined by the following reference: H. Alvestrand, ed. RFC 3066: Tags for the Identification of Languages 1995. Available at: <a href="http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3066.txt">http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3066.txt</a> .\n</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Examples</td>
			<td><ul class="list-group list-group-flush">
  <li class="list-group-item">en</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">en-US</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">UND</li>
</ul></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Type</td>
			<td>Property</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<table>
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<th colspan="2"><a id="abcd2_Gathering-Country-NameDerived"></a>Term Name  abcd2:Gathering-Country-NameDerived</th>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>Term IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Gathering-Country-NameDerived">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Gathering-Country-NameDerived</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Modified</td>
			<td></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Term version IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Gathering-Country-NameDerived-2024-11-13">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Gathering-Country-NameDerived-2024-11-13</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>NameDerived</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>The derived full name of the country or major region where the specimen was collected, or the observation made, interpreted in the light of contemporary geographical knowledge.<br/><br/>The use of this element is slightly ambiguous in that local practice might require either a verbatim quote from specimen labels, or standardisation by controlled vocabulary or lookup lists.<br/><br/>It is recommended that the spelling of the country should be that which is recognised by the International Standards Organisation (ISO).<br/><br/>The derived country name offers the opportunity to document the name under which a country is currently known, interpreted from an old or superceded name on the specimen label (e.g. Vanuatu for the New Hebrides, Sri Lanka for Ceylon, etc).<br/><br/>Separate fields for state/province and country are needed to adequately handle the situation with international collections.<br/><br/>If the name of the country where the plant was collected is unknown, then this field should contain the value 'UNKNOWN'. In this case, the ISO Code for Country of Origin field must have the entry 'XX', 'XY',  'XXX', or 'XXY'. All remaining 'location group' fields should be left unfilled.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Examples</td>
			<td><ul class="list-group list-group-flush">
  <li class="list-group-item">Sri Lanka</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Taiwan</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Vanuatu</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Papua New Guinea</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Kiribati</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">East Timor</li>
</ul></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Type</td>
			<td>Property</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<table>
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<th colspan="2"><a id="abcd2_Gathering-DateTime-DateText"></a>Term Name  abcd2:Gathering-DateTime-DateText</th>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>Term IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Gathering-DateTime-DateText">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Gathering-DateTime-DateText</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Modified</td>
			<td></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Term version IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Gathering-DateTime-DateText-2024-11-13">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Gathering-DateTime-DateText-2024-11-13</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>DateText</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>A text version (alphabetic mixed case and integer) of the date that the gathering event took place. This element is meant for use when the date is imprecise, ambiguous or not in a form that satisfies the standard structured date format. It can also be used when it is important to record the verbatim representation of the date or when dates to be recorded are not completely legible. For example the day and month may be decipherable but not the year; the use of this field will allow recording of partially interpreted information. <br/><br/>This field can be used to record generalised date ranges and irresolvable ambiguity such as different day/month order conventions (e.g. US/Europe) or to allow for multiple dates and periods. <br/><br/>In the rare instances of dates for periods before the year 0000, BC and similar dates can be recorded in this field.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Examples</td>
			<td><ul class="list-group list-group-flush">
  <li class="list-group-item">25 [?] 1925</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">3/9/45 [ambiguous day month]</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Spring 1912</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Late 1800s</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">End of 19th Century</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Mid 1978</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Easter 1933</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Post WW2</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">Before June 25, 2000</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">After June 25, 2000</li>
</ul></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Type</td>
			<td>Property</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>ISODateTimeBegin</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>The exact date (and time) or beginning of a period representing the gathering event, expressed in a modified ISO/ANSI 8601 standard structured date format.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Usage</td>
			<td>The date format looks like this: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS with flexible precision.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Notes</td>
			<td>The date format looks like this: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS with flexible precision.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Examples</td>
			<td>2005-04-10T17:34:56\n2005-04-10T17:34\n2005-04-10T17\n2005-04-10\n2005-04\n2005</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Type</td>
			<td>Property</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

			<td>Label</td>
			<td>PeriodExplicit</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>This is an indicator for the expliciteness of the gathering event time period. <br/><br/>This is set to 'true' if the gathering event takes place for the period indicated. It is set to \nfalse' if it occurs at some point of time during the period, and is not filled if unknown or if no period is specified.</td>
		</tr>

			<td><ul class="list-group list-group-flush">
  <li class="list-group-item">true</li>

		</tr>

  <li class="list-group-item">04.25</li>
</ul></td>

<table>
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<th colspan="2"><a id="abcd2_Gathering-FootprintSpatialFit"></a>Term Name  abcd2:Gathering-FootprintSpatialFit</th>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>Term IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Gathering-FootprintSpatialFit">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Gathering-FootprintSpatialFit</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Modified</td>
			<td></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Term version IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Gathering-FootprintSpatialFit-2024-11-13">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Gathering-FootprintSpatialFit-2024-11-13</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>FootprintSpatialFit</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>[DwC Geospacial Extension Schema v. 0.3] A measure of how well the geometry expressed in the footprint match the original spatial representation, as a ratio of the area of the footprint given to the area of the original spatial representation. Legal values are 0, greater than or equal to 1, or undefined. A value of 1 is an exact match or 100% overlap. A value of 0 should be used if the given georeference does not completely contain the original representation. The FootprintSpatialFit is undefined if the original representation is a point without uncertainty and the given georeference is not that same point (without uncertainty). If both the original and the given georeference are the same point, the FootprintSpatialFit is 1. Detailed explanations with graphical examples can be found in the Guide to Best Practices for Georeferencing (Chapman and Wieczorek, eds. 2006)</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Type</td>
			<td>Property</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>FootprintWKT</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>[DwC Geospacial Extension Schema v. 0.3]. A Well-Known Text (WKT; see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Well-known_text) representation of the the shape (footprint) that defines the location of the occurrence. Example: the one-degree box with opposite corners at (longitude=10, latitude=20) and (longitude=11, latitude=21) would be expressed in well-known text as POLYGON ((10 20, 11 20, 11 21, 10 21, 10 20))</td>
		</tr>

			<td>Property</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>

	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>Term IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Gathering-LocalityText">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Gathering-LocalityText</a></td>
		</tr>

			<td>Modified</td>
			<td></td>
		</tr>

			<td>Term version IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Gathering-LocalityText-2024-11-13">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Gathering-LocalityText-2024-11-13</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>LocalityText</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>The original gathering locality data as appearing on a label or in an original entry, as a text string. This field should be transcribed verbatim from the specimen label.<br/><br/>Location information below the country level that describes where the accession was collected. This might include the distance in kilometres and direction from the nearest town, village or map grid reference point. A FAO/IPGRI multi-crop passport descriptor (MCPD), description and examples taken from EURISCO descriptor list dated July 3, 2002.<br/><br/>Where possible, the language of the label locality should be indicated with the language attribute.<br/><br/>Editorial omissions for brevity, etc. should be indicated with an ellipsis (...) and interpreted or implied text should be included in square brackets [ ].</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Examples</td>
			<td><ul class="list-group list-group-flush">
  <li class="list-group-item">New Caledonia, below summit region of Mt Mou.</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">New South Wales, Central Tablelands 12 km SW of Armidale.</li>
  <li class="list-group-item">7 km south of Curitiba in the state of Parana</li>
</ul></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Type</td>
			<td>Property</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>

		</tr>
		<tr>

</ul></td>

<table>
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<th colspan="2"><a id="abcd2_Gathering-PointRadiusSpatialFit"></a>Term Name  abcd2:Gathering-PointRadiusSpatialFit</th>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>Term IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Gathering-PointRadiusSpatialFit">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/Gathering-PointRadiusSpatialFit</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Modified</td>
			<td></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Term version IRI</td>
			<td><a href="http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Gathering-PointRadiusSpatialFit-2024-11-13">http://rs.tdwg.org/abcd2/terms/version/Gathering-PointRadiusSpatialFit-2024-11-13</a></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Label</td>
			<td>PointRadiusSpatialFit</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>DwC Geospatial Extension v. 1.4: ] A measure of how well the circle defined by the coordinates and uncertainty match the original spatial representation, as a ratio of the area of the circle to the area of the original spatial representation. Legal values are 0, greater than or equal to 1, or undefined. A value of 1 is an exact match or 100% overlap. A value of 0 should be used if the given georeference does not completely contain the original representation. The PointRadiusSpatialFit is undefined if the original representation is a point without uncertainty and the given georeference is not that same point (without uncertainty). If both the original and the given georeference are the same point, the PointRadiusSpatialFit is 1. Detailed explanations with graphical examples can be found in the Guide to Best Practices for Georeferencing (Chapman and Wieczorek, eds. 2006).</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Type</td>
			<td>Property</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

			<td>The value UND (undefined) should be used if the language cannot be set for some reason. However, use of UND is discouraged by the W3 consortium.\n\nRecommended values are defined by the following reference: H. Alvestrand, ed. RFC 3066: Tags for the Identification of Languages 1995. Available at: <a href="http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3066.txt">http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3066.txt</a> .\n</td>

			<td>Notes</td>
			<td>The value UND (undefined) should be used if the language cannot be set for some reason. However, use of UND is discouraged by the W3 consortium.\n\nRecommended values are defined by the following reference: H. Alvestrand, ed. RFC 3066: Tags for the Identification of Languages 1995. Available at: <a href="http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3066.txt">http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3066.txt</a> .\n</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>

			<td>Label</td>
			<td>TelephoneNumber</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Definition</td>
			<td>Telephone or fax number for the unit sequencing agent.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Usage</td>
			<td>Numbers should be provided in the ITU (International Telecommunication Union) international format ("+Country-Code Area-Code Number").  \n\nThe preferred attribute @preferred indicates the preferred number.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Notes</td>
			<td>Numbers should be provided in the ITU (International Telecommunication Union) international format ("+Country-Code Area-Code Number").  \n\nThe preferred attribute @preferred indicates the preferred number.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Examples</td>
			<td>+44 9876 543210</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Type</td>
			<td>Class</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>
